title: Protocol for deep proteomic profiling of formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded specimens using a spectral library-free approach
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
FFPE sample preparation for proteomics analysis
Timing: 30 min
      This step outlines the procedure for retrieving the FFPE tissue samples
      from the glass slide.
    
        Start with FFPE tissue sections that are 10 μm thick and mounted on a
        glass slide.
        
            Use a Sharpie marker to mark the tissue area on the back side of the
            glass slide.
          
            Scrape only the tissue from the marked area using a scalpel blade,
            leaving excess wax on the slide.
          
Note: In Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1],
      marking areas 1 and area 2 are approximately 8 × 5 mm on the glass slide,
      which provides sufficient starting material.
    
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Fig1.jpg
          Figure 1. FFPE tissue scrapping from the glass slide
        
          (A) Mark the tissue area on the back side of the tissue on the glass
          slide.
        
          (B) Scrape the tissue from the marked area and leave the excess wax.
        
          (C) Transfer the scraped tissue to new 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes
          containing a single magnetic bead from the Beatbox kit, and briefly
          centrifuge.
        
        Transfer the scraped tissue into new 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes that
        contain a single magnetic bead from the Preomics Beatbox kit.
      
FFPE tissue lysis and de-crosslinking
Timing: 2 h
This step describes how to lyse and de-crosslink FFPE tissue.
        FFPE tissue lysis, homogenization and de-crosslinking.
        
            Add 100 μL of tissue lysis buffer into each sample from step 2 and
            sonicate for 2 min in a water bath.
          
            Place each sample into the BeatBox holder for tissue lysis and
            homogenization.
          
            Select the high-power setting of BeatBox and run it for 10 min at
            room temperature.
          
            Collect the solubilized protein lysate by placing the tubes on a
            magnetic rack and transfer it to new 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes.
          
            Incubate each sample on a ThermoMixer at 95°C/1400 rpm for 90 min.

Remove the samples from the ThermoMixer and let them incubate at
            room temperature for 10 min.
          
Reduction and alkylation
Timing: 30 min
      This step outlines the process for reducing and alkylating solubilized
      protein.
    
        Reduction and alkylation.
        
            Add 10 μL of Reduction/Alkylation mix to each sample and incubate
            for 10 min at 45°C/1400 rpm in a thermomixer.
          
            Incubate for 5 min at room temperature and sonicate it for 2 min in
            water bath.
          
Protein lysate cleanup with the SP3 method
Timing: 30 min
      These steps involve the removal of detergents, which were used to
      solubilize proteins during the lysis process, and paraffin, which can
      interfere with protein digestion.
    
        Prepare SP3 magnetic beads and clean up the tissue lysate.
        
            Combine Sera-Mag Speed A and B beads (supplied at 50 mg/mL) in a new
            1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube to prepare 100 μL of SP3 magnetic beads
            mix for 10 samples.
          
            Thoroughly mix the beads by gently vortexing with 50 μL of each
            bead.
          
            Place the tube on a magnetic rack to remove the storage buffer.
          
            Wash the bead pellet three times with 200 μL of 80% acetone without
            disturbing the pellet on the magnetic rack.
          
            Re-suspend the SP3 beads in 100 μL of 80% acetone for a final
            working concentration of 50 μg/μL.
            
Note: SP36[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
              method is modified.
            
            Add 10 μL of washed SP3 beads, 400 μL of 80% acetone, and 100 mM
            NaCl to each sample from step 4b.
          
            Mix the sample by gentle vortexing and incubate for 5 min on ice,
            followed by 1 min of incubation on a magnetic rack.
          
            Remove the supernatant without disturbing the SP3 bead pellet and
            wash the pellet twice with 400 μL of 80% acetone while on the
            magnetic rack. Then, remove the buffer.

Resuspend the SP3 bead pellet in 50 μL of digestion buffer by gentle
            vortexing.
          
Protein digestion and de-salting
Timing: 14–15 h
      This step includes two procedures: protein digestion and preparation of
      high-capacity SDB-RPS stage tips for peptide desalting.
    
        Protein digestion.
        
            Add 2.5 μL of a freshly prepared Lys-C/Trypsin mix (0.5 μg) to each
            sample from step 5i.
          
Digest proteins overnight at 37°C/1200 rpm on a thermomixer.
            After brief centrifuging, place the tubes on a magnetic rack and
            transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5 mL microcentrifuge. Then,
            resuspend the SP3 bead pellet in 20 μL of MQ H2O and wash
            at 37°C/1200 rpm for 5 min on a ThermoMixer.
          
            Place the tubes on a magnetic rack and transfer the wash to the
            supernatant collected in step 6c, resulting in a total volume of
            72.5 μL.
          
            Acidify each sample by adding 7.25 μL of 10% TFA solution, resulting
            in a final concentration of 1% TFA. The addition of TFA will cause
            SDC to precipitate, and the sample will become cloudy.
          
            Centrifuge each sample for 5 min at 10,000 × g using a
            benchtop centrifuge to separate the precipitate.
            
Note: Use the pH strip to verify
              that the pH level of the solution is between 2–3.
            
            Prepare the StageTip and peptide desalting.
            
                Insert one Empore SDB-RPS disk core into a P200 pipette tip by
                using a 14-gauge blunt-ended syringe needle. Carefully pack the
                disk at the broad end of the tip using a gel-loader tip. Then,
                position the StageTip on the tip holder and assemble it into a
                1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube.
              
                Load the samples from step 6f onto the StageTip and centrifuge
                for 2 min at 2000 rpm.
              
                Wash with 200 μL of ethyl acetate buffer followed by 200 μL of

wash buffer in a centrifuge at 3000 rpm for 2 min.
              
                Elute the de-salted peptides with 40 μL of elution buffer into
                new 1.5 mL microcentrifuge and dry them in a SpeedVac centrifuge
                at 45°C.
                
Note: C18-StageTip can be used
                  for desalting peptides.
                
Pause point: The
                  protocol can be paused here by storing the samples at −80°C
                  for a long period of time.
                
                Reconstitute the dried peptides in 10 μL of peptide resuspension
                buffer and thoroughly mix the solution. Subsequently, sonicate
                the sample in a water bath for 2 min, followed by centrifugation
                for 2 min at 10,000 × g. Measure the peptide
                concentration at 280 nm using a NanoDrop.
              
                Adjust the peptide concentration to 200 ng/μL with peptide
                resuspension buffer.
                
Note: Starting with FFPE
                  tissue sections that are 10 μm thick and marking Area 1 and
                  Area 2 on the glass slide will yield around 1.5–2 μg of
                  peptide.
                
                Transfer each sample to autosampler vials for MS analysis.
              
Mass spectrometry parameters for data acquisition
Timing: 90 min/sample (for steps 7 to 9)
    
      This section includes the detailed settings required for the diaPASEF7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]
      run.
    
        Inject 200 ng of peptides onto a reversed-phase C18 column with an
        integrated CaptiveSpray Emitter (25 cm × 75 μm, 1.6 μm, IonOpticks) in
        the timsTOF Pro mass spectrometer.
      
        Elute the peptides from the column using mobile phases A and B with 0.1%
        formic acid in water and 0.1% formic acid in acetonitrile, respectively,
        at a flow rate of 400 nL/min over 90 min. Gradually increase the
        fraction of Mobile Phase B with a linear gradient from 2% to 25% over
        60 min, followed by a further increase to 35% within 10 min, and then
        increase to 80% before re-equilibration, while keeping the column at a
        constant temperature of 50°C.

The data acquisition settings are listed below:
table:files/protocols_protocol_2774_12.csv
table:files/protocols_protocol_2774_13.csv
Note: If a different MS instrument is
      used, the settings may need to be optimized.
    
Protein identification and quantification using DIA-NN
Timing: 1 day
      This step outlines the use of DIA-NN software to perform a proteomic
      search of the raw MS files. We recommend using the latest version of
      DIA-NN, which includes the newest features and search algorithm updates.
      In our analysis, we used version DIA-NN 1.8.2 beta 11, but other software
      can also be used with parameters adjusted accordingly.
    
        DIA-NN - a universal software for data-independent acquisition (DIA)
        proteomics data processing by Demichev, Ralser, and Lilley labs.
        DIA-NN5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3] uses deep neural networks (DNNs) and several
        algorithms that enable reliable, robust, and quantitatively accurate
        large-scale experiments using high-throughput methods. The DIA-NN
        pipeline is fully automated and includes both an intuitive graphical
        interface and a command line tool, with results being reported in a
        simple text format.
      
Note: Spectronaut,8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]
      FragPipe,9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5] and MaxQuant10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6] are
      commonly used software tools for proteomics data analysis.
    
        Use the DIA-NN search engine with default settings of the spectral
        library-free search algorithm (as shown in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2])
        to search the acquired diaPASEF raw files against the UniProt Human
        proteome Swiss-Prot database (UP000005640).
        
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Fig2.jpg
              Figure. 2. DIA-NN search engine and parameters used for diaPASEF
              search
            
Note: By starting with FFPE tissue
      sections that are 10 μm thick and marking area 1 and area 2 on a glass
      slide, this workflow is able to identify and quantify over 6000 protein
      groups and more than 55,000 peptides in each sample with a 200 ng peptide
      injection (Table S2[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc2.xlsx]: DIA-NN search_DIA_NN.stats). This study represents the most extensive
      proteome profiling of FFPE tissue to date, achieving a level of depth that

has not been previously attained in a single run without the use of a
      spectral library.
    
Note:
Table S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc1.xlsx]: Reports.pg_matrix
    
Note:
Table S2[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc2.xlsx]: DIA-NN search_DIA_NN.stats
    
Note: Normalization can be performed in
      various ways, such as global normalization and RT-dependent normalization,
      depending on the experiment.
    
      Differential protein expression (DEP) and gene ontology analysis
    
Timing: 1–2 h
      This step describes the procedures for performing a differential protein
      expression (DPE) analysis and a Gene Ontology (GO) analysis, which
      provides functional annotations for the identified proteins.
    
Download and install Perseus software.
Note: Perseus software can be freely
      downloaded at
      https://maxquant.net/perseus/[href=https://maxquant.net/perseus/].
    
Note: Perseus version 1.6.15.0 was used.
    
        Differential protein expression (DEP)
        
            Import Reports.pg_matrix, the output generated by DIA-NN, into the
            Perseus statistical package for data processing.
          
            Perform Student’s t-test on log-transformed data using default
            settings to determine the statistical significance of differentially
            expressed proteins (DEPs).
          
            Refer to Tyanova et al.4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7] for a description of
            the statistical analysis performed in Perseus.
          
Note:
Table S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc1.xlsx]: Reports.pg_matrix
    
Note: Perseus tutorial are available on
      YouTube:
      https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MsSiqpMBfRc[href=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MsSiqpMBfRc]
Note: Statistical tools, such as R
      packages LIMMA, edgeR, and others, can be used for identifying
      differentially expressed proteins (DEPs).
    
        R software and RStudio1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]:
        https://www.rproject.org/[href=https://www.rproject.org/]
https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/[href=https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/],
      
Note: The R software version 4.2.3 and
      RStudio version 2023.03.0 + 386 were used for this data analysis.
    
        GO enrichment2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]:
        https://github.com/YuLab-SMU/clusterProfiler[href=https://github.com/YuLab-SMU/clusterProfiler]
Note: GSEA, ShinyGO, Enrichr, and DAVID
      are commonly used tools for functional enrichment analysis.
    
        Volcano plot3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]:
        https://github.com/kevinblighe/EnhancedVolcano[href=https://github.com/kevinblighe/EnhancedVolcano]
Note: VolcanoPlotR, Perseus, and GraphPad
      are commonly used tools for visualizing and analyzing proteomics data.
    
Installs and loads packages into R Studio.
> install.packages(“EnhancedVolcano”)
> install.packages(“ClusterProfiler”)
> install.packages(“dplyr”)
> install.packages(“ggplot2”)
> install.packages(“xlsx”)
> library(EnhancedVolcano)
> library(ClusterProfiler)
> library(ggplot2)
> library(dplyr)
> library(xlsx)
        Visualize the differentially expressed proteins (DEPs) by using the
        EnhancedVolcano package in R Studio with the following code.
        
Note: Load the output generated by

Perseus for differentially expressed proteins (DEPs), specifically
          Table S3[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc3.xlsx]
          VolcanoPlot.
        
Note: Convert the Excel file “Table S3[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc3.xlsx]. VolcanoPlot” to CSV format.
        
            Read data from CSV file.
            
>DEP_FFPE_Tissues<-read.csv("Table S3[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc3.xlsx]. VolcanoPlot.csv",header=T)
Simply run the following to generate the volcano plot.
>EnhancedVolcano(DEP_FFPE_Tissues,lab=DEP_FFPE_Tissues$Genes,x =
          'Log2FC',y = 'Pvalue',pCutoff = 0.05,FCcutoff =
          1,pointSize = 2.0,labSize =3.0,boxedLabels = FALSE,xlim = c(-8,
          8),ylim = c(0,8),legendPosition = 'top',colAlpha = 1, col =
          c("black", "#f7ca64",
          "#46bac2","#7e62a3"), legendLabSize =
          14,legendIconSize = 4.0,drawConnectors = TRUE, widthConnectors =
          1,colConnectors = 'black',xlab =
          "Log2FC",titleLabSize= 24)
Note: In Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A, a
      Volcano Plot was generated, and the data used for this plot can be found
      in
      Table S3[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc3.xlsx], specifically labeled as VolcanoPlot.
    
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Fig3.jpg
          Figure 3. The results of the differential protein expression and Gene
          Ontology analysis are presented
        
          The data analysis settings are described above and provided in the R
          codes.
        
          (A) shows the VolcanoPlot created using the EnhancedVolcano package,
          with significantly changed protein abundance determined by a threshold
          for significance of p < 0.05 (permutation-based FDR correction) and
          a 1.0 log2FC.
        
          (B and C) (B) and (C) display the results of GO and functional
          analysis for brain-specific and breast-specific significantly enriched
          proteins, respectively, using the ClusterProfiler package.
        
        Perform GO and functional analysis of differentially expressed proteins
        (DEPs) by executing the following code in R Studio using the
        ClusterProfiler package.
        
Note: DEPs table from Perseus should
          be separated into two tables: Brain-Specific DEPs with log2FC > 1,
          and Breast-Specific DEPs with Log2FC < −1.
        
Note: Convert the Excel file “Table S4[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc4.xlsx]
          Brain-Specific DEPs” to CSV format.
        
            Read data from CSV file.
            
>DEP_FFPE_Tissue_BrainSpecific<-read.csv("Table S4[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc4.xlsx]Brain-Specific DEPs.csv",header=T)
            Simply run the following to filter the genes and convert them into
            Entrez gene ID.
            
>all_gene_id_BrainSpecific<-DEP_FFPE_Tissue_BrainSpecific$Genes
>all_gene_id_BrainSpecific_to_ENTREZID =
                  bitr(all_gene_id_BrainSpecific, fromType="SYMBOL",
                  toType="ENTREZID",
                  OrgDb="org.Hs.eg.db")
            Perform the gene ontology over-representation test using the
            enrichGO() function implemented in the clusterProfiler package.
            
>EnrichGO_all_BrainSpecific<-enrichGO(gene =
                  all_gene_id_BrainSpecific_to_ENTREZID$ENTREZID,OrgDb =

org.Hs.eg.db,ont= "all", pAdjustMethod =
                  "BH",pvalueCutoff = 0.05,
qvalueCutoff = 0.2,readable = TRUE)
            Simply run the following to visualize the dot plot of enriched
            terms.
            
>p1 <- dotplot(EnrichGO_all_BrainSpecific,
                  split="ONTOLOGY") + facet_grid(ONTOLOGY∼.,
                  scale="free")
>p2 <- p1 + scale_y_discrete(labels = function(y)
                  str_wrap(y, width = 50))
>p3 <- p2 +
                  scale_color_gradientn(colours=c("#f7ca64",
                  "#46bac2","#7e62a3"),trans =
                  "log10",guide=guide_colorbar(reverse=TRUE,order=1))
>p3
Note: Convert the Excel file “Table S5[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc5.xlsx]. Breast-Specific DEPs” to CSV format.
            
            Read data from CSV file.
            
>DEP_FFPE_Tissue_BreastSpecific<-read.csv("Table S5[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc5.xlsx]. Breast-Specific DEPs.csv",header=T)
            Simply run the following to filter the genes and convert them into
            Entrez gene ID.
            
>all_gene_id_BreastSpecific<-DEP_FFPE_Tissue_BreastSpecific$Genes
>all_gene_id_BreastSpecific_to_ENTREZID =
                  bitr(all_gene_id_BreastSpecific, fromType="SYMBOL",
                  toType="ENTREZID",
                  OrgDb="org.Hs.eg.db")
            Perform the gene ontology over-representation test using the
            enrichGO() function implemented in the clusterProfiler package.
            
>EnrichGO_all_BreastSpecific<-enrichGO(gene =
                  all_gene_id_BreastSpecific_to_ENTREZID$ENTREZID,
OrgDb = org.Hs.e.g.,.db, ont =
                  "all",pAdjustMethod = "BH", pvalueCutoff =
                  0.05,qvalueCutoff = 0.2,readable = TRUE)
            Simply run the following to visualize the dot plot of enriched
            terms.
          
p1 <- dotplot(EnrichGO_all_BreastSpecific,
          split="ONTOLOGY") + facet_grid(ONTOLOGY∼.,
          scale="free")
>p2 <- p1 + scale_y_discrete(labels = function(y) str_wrap(y,
          width = 50))
>p3 <- p2 +
          scale_color_gradientn(colours=c("#f7ca64","#46bac2","#7e62a3"),trans =
          "log10",guide=guide_colorbar(reverse=TRUE,order=1))
>p3
Note: In Figures 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B
      and 3C, a GO (Gene Ontology) and functional analysis dot plot were
      generated, and the data used for these plots can be found in
      Table S4[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc4.xlsx]
      and
      S5[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc5.xlsx], respectively. In
      Table S4[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc4.xlsx], the data is labeled as "Brain-Specific DEPs," while in
      Table S5[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2774-Mmc5.xlsx], it is labeled as "Breast-Specific DEPs.
